To Whom it May Concern,
My name is Carly and I am a 22 year old college student preparing to graduate in less than one month with a Bachelors degree in Sustainability and a concentration in Policy and Economy. Upon graduation, I am looking to accept a position within my local municipal government and get involved with other projects in my field. 
I strongly oppose the DEAs decision to classify the kratom plant as a Schedule 1 controlled substance. I have been using kratom for a little over a year when I began suffering from anxiety and depression. I had just transferred down to southern New Jersey after getting my associates degree and stumbled into a relationship that quickly turned unhealthy. I have always been independent and autonomous, so I was able to get out in the longest four months of my life, but I couldnt shake the negative thoughts and overwhelming edge that he would keep me on. I tried counseling, but I felt they didnt understand how I was feeling. A few of my friends have prescriptions for Xanax and Lipitor, but I knew I just needed time and didnt want to have to worry about upping the dosage or becoming reliant (I have a bad history with Adderall as a college student). My younger brother had asked me if I knew about kratom, as he had just been in a tragic accident that resulted in his friends death after being in the wrong place at the wrong time and was suffering from PTSD. I found a reputable distributor and decided to try it. 
Flash forward, my rebound guy ended up being the love of my life, and weve been together for a year and a half. Soon after we started dating, I found out hed been living with a heroin addiction for the better part of six years. He tried to go to rehab, but it was impossible without insurance. I realized after my last relationship, which I did not invest much into, the proper way to treat people that you care about and how to foster a healthy relationship. Together, we are getting through our issues and hes been clean about eight months, since we started living together. We could not have done it without kratom. In addiction recovery, every person is different in their mental fortitude and their confidence to get through it. Over time, the temptation to use goes from every 15 minutes, to every hour, to eventually a few times a week, sometimes never completely dissipating. After a user has built up their tolerance to a certain point, it no longer becomes about getting high but rather feeling normal. Not only does kratom take away the intensity of withdrawal, but it gives you the esteem to know you can get through the entire day without needing that extra chemical in your bloodstream. 
One cannot know the pain of drug addiction unless they personally experience it, whether themselves or through a loved one. Unfortunately, there are millions of kratom users whose addictions stem from pain medications. Regardless of how we got to where we are, there are over 23 million Americans living with drug and alcohol additions throughout the United States. For too long, weve allowed ourselves into bed with Big Pharma assuming their intentions were good. I believe kratom offers the chance to change that.  Thank you for your time and please consider this in your decision to classify kratom as a Schedule 1 controlled substance. 
Sincerely, 
Carly Griffiths

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I suffer from chronic pain due to intractable migraine attacks. Six years ago, I had a migraine attack that has never ended. Some days are better than others, some weeks and some months. There is no cure for migraine disease. Im on a constant journey to find better ways to manage my pain. 

I believe in a mix of medication and self-healing measures, such as yoga and meditation. I also believe that its not good practice to rely only on one medication for pain management. My headache specialist and I have agreed that diversification of pain medication helps to reduce the risk of dependence on any one drug. 

This summer a friend of mine sent me an article from Vice News about kratom (http://www.vice.com/read/why-banning-the-controversial-painkiller-kratom-could-be-bad-news-for-americas-heroin-addicts), a natural substance known for its pain relieving qualities. Could this be another way to manage my pain? Maybe this would replace or cut out other pain meds that I use. I took to the internet to obtain facts, check on addiction rates and understand how to ingest kratom. Here are some of the facts I found that made me decide that I would try kratom as one of many branches in managing chronic pain.
 
	It is known to be a natural analgesic, muscle relaxer, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant (https://www.kratomscience.com/kratom-legality). I currently three medications that address these issues.
	According to Kratom Science (https://www.kratomscience.com/2015/07/31/kratom-evaluating-the-perception-of-a-controversial-drug), an important distinction is that unlike other administered drugs such as oxycodone and morphine, kratom exhibits less dependency and addiction potential on the user. Over the last 6 years of using Percoset, I have only needed to increase the dose once to 7.5mg as my body had adjusted the prior dose and was not finding relief in a smaller dose of 5mg. As mentioned previously, I am very cognizant of not becoming too dependent on any one substance and believe that diversification with kratom can be beneficial to my pain management plan. 
	Vice News reports that it is used to wean addicts off of heroin. 
	Those with multiple sclerosis, back pain, chronic fatigue syndrome and Lyme disease have reported relief when using kratom. 
	There have been a limited number of deaths attributed solely to kratom. Only 15 reported in the last 10 years. The majority of overdoses where kratom is present, other drugs and alcohol were all contributing factors.  Unlike opioids, kratom does not suppress the breathing function, which is an element of overdosing. 

These findings led me to try kratom. After trying different strains and dosing, I can say that my pain level decreases with use. I have not found any medication that completely takes away my pain. Kratom definitely knocks my pain down a few levels and gives me about 4-5 hours of relief. I found that it gives me a little boost, allowing me to be more productive. I have been pleased with the results and it is a great addition to my pain management tool box.  

Over 100,000 Americans signed a petition (including myself) to halt the DEAs two-year ban on kratom. During the temporary ban, the DEA would conduct studies on this natural supplement. To me, it makes more sense to conduct studies and then come to a conclusion on whether or not to ban kratom. It clearly helps at least 100,000 manage their pain in an era where taking any type of opioid is completely taboo. People with pain matter. Completely blocking access to kratom will have a direct impact on those who responsibly take pain medications to deal with a chronic medical issue. 

In conclusion, I urge the DEA to halt the ban until further studies can be performed. I believe that I represent the majority of patients with chronic pain who use opioids. We are responsible and educated. Yes, there is an opioid epidemic in this country. However, taking away a natural supplement that could replace an opioid as pain management doesnt make any sense. 

Sincerely,

Katie M. Golden
US Pain Foundation Ambassador & Patient Advocate

documents.commentText:
I am a public health social worker and I oversee SUD treatment services at an FQHC.  I have been following recent developments around the DEA's decision to classify Kratom as a Schedule I substance.  I find Kratom to be an interesting substance in the greater conversation around harm reduction, and I also find it deeply troubling that in the midst of an increasingly out of control overdose epidemic, there is support behind the tightest restriction of controlling a substance which has been shown to reduce the risks associated with opioid use. We are concerned about heroin, carefentinil, or U-47700 humans have continuously sought out opioid receptor activation in the pursuit of some sort of relief.  Law and interdiction have never been shown to produce outcomes which show health improvements, and only seem to net financial gains for law enforcement.

Why I am troubled, is complex.  I believe strongly that the continued involvement of law enforcement as a way to combat substance use has had limited efficacy in the promotion of safety in the US.  Folks have used illicit substances for the duration of our nation's history and use greater and more varied novel agents, likely due to the criminalization of more standard drugs of abuse.  Individuals who are addicted to opioids continue to find themselves with fewer pathways to harm reduction, and illicit heroin/fentanyl (you can barely separate the two anymore) production continues to increase in risk to customers in that market at an alarming rate.  The plant, Kratom, has been used for thousands of years in south east Asia, and remains a common social, medicinal, and performance enhancer in such countries as Thailand and Malaysia.  Use of this plant as an alternative to illicit and pharmaceutical opioids has been shown much less adverse effects on breathing, and is unlikely to cause overdose.

I am by no means advocating for kratom to replace medication assisted treatments like methadone or buprenorphine or other evidence-based interventions, but I certainly think that if someone can transition off of riskier drugs onto something like kratom, I would support it whole-heartedly.  Many of the newer synthetic agents we are seeing in street drug use carry much higher risks.  When compared to fentanyl, heroin or even pharmaceutical opioids, Kratom does not come close in terms of risk.  We have people who have been electing to shift from a dangerous, unpredictable, and increasingly uncertain illicit drugs, as well as those choosing to self-manage pain as access to pharmaceutical sources have become more expensive and tightly regulated due to fears of misuse.  

Regarding the 660 poison control cases: An average of 110 cases a year may sound like a lot, but it's not. It represents about 0.004 percent of the 3 million or so calls received by poison control centers each year. By comparison, exposures involving analgesics accounted for nearly 300,000 calls in 2014, while cosmetics and personal care products, cleaning solutions, antidepressants, and antihistamines each accounted for more than 100,000. This does not mention that two-thirds of the cases were deemed "minor" or "moderate," while only 7 percent (eight per year) were described as "life-threatening." The CDC noted a single death in six years, "reported in a person who was exposed to the medications paroxetine (an antidepressant) and lamotrigine (an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer) in addition to kratom.

Regarding the 15 deaths: The DEA's list of other kratom-associated deaths primarily described polypharmacy as a factor in those fatalities, many of which involved benzodiazepines, sleep-inducing hypnotics such as zopiclone, and opioids such as fentanyl.

Kratom results in microscopic rates of poison control calls compared to OTC analgesics or household cleaning products.  This drug which, when (and only when) combined with known killers in and of themselves such as fentanyl, alcohol, and benzodiazepines, has resulted in 15 deaths in a 2 year period. This drug holds the same possible side-effect profile as most non-classified, common drugs which many of our patients, family members, friends, and ourselves take regularly.  Caffeine, nicotine, alcohol, and acetaminophen each pose a greater public health concern

This action will drive self-managers back into more dangerous markets. The expense of trying to access buprenorphine services in can be cost prohibitive and is more difficult to withdraw from. Treatment providers as a community have taken many great steps to address the risks associated with opioid use.  It is a dangerous mistake to disallow people the liberty to make reasonable decisions on their own behalf.  There is no evidence that kratom is contributing to overdoses, or that children are suddenly more at risk for opioid use or dependence.  The treatment community is far more concerned with heroin, fentanyl, and pharmaceutical opioid use.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement commonly known as kratom. There should be no prohibition. 

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Research seems to indicate Kratom to works using a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies. (see http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6)

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes that Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
(see http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v)

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. 

Meanwhile, the opioid painkillers currently being prescribed are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet, the FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. 

Kratom should not be a controlled substance!

Good afternoon, 

I am writing this letter to give my position, and personal experiences with the plant Kratom. 

I am strongly apposed to the DEA's ruling to ban Kratom. From what I understand, this stems from a lack of responsiveness from the FDA providing any clinical health benefits/ or consequences. 

I can only provide anteqdotal evidence here, but I have substantial knowledge, and experience. I even wrote a senior thesis for my Economics degree that involved kratom, as a subject in underground economies. 

Just a side note: my primary possession in my thesis was the enormous benefit that the public would have from a public health position should Kratom be thoroughly researched as an alternative for opioid addicts, Alcoholics, PTSD victims, treatment resistant depression, and more. Also the forecasted tax revenue for States/ Federal institutions should this be added to an Alcohol/ and Tobacco type of tax classification. 

I am a small business owner, consultant, and on The Ohio State University young economics society advisory board and I am a responsible Kratom user. 

I have used the plant since 2011. It started as means to stop using pain medication. I underwent 4 foot/ ankle surgeries from 2010-2011 from a very bad wakeboading injury. I separated every major ligament in my foot, and nearly resulted in amputation. 

Following the operation, I was heavily reliant on pain medication, with a disturbing amount of encouragement from my orthopedic surgeon, as well as the entire medical community who worked together to help rehabilitate my injury. 

This left me addicted to opioids. I was a person that I hardly recognized. I had thoughts, and urges towards the medication that was spiraling out of control. It wasn't until I was on the edge, and close to resorting to Heroin that I discovered this incredible plant.

I used Kratom to wean myself away from opioids, with very minimal discomfort, and mental tourture. This saved my life. I still to this day use the plant 3-4 times a week when my foot pain is too much to bare. If not for this natural remedy, I would still likely be reliant on pain meds, and with the addictive tendencies I had towards that never ending "dragon" I would likely be dead. 

I have stopped using the plant for weeks at a time with literally no side effects/ or withdraw, except for a mild runny nose. There are times when I still crave pain medication to the point of torture, and Kratom completely alleviates those urges. I can carry on with my life, and producing to society without this metaphorical gorilla on my back that is opioid medication. 

I firmly believe this plant can cause a HUGE public health revolution in helping addicts everywhere. 

One more note: I am from rural southern Ohio, where along with KY, and WV the opioid epidemic is unreal. Most of my classmates, and community peers are addicted, in jail, or dead. Every person that I have reached out to with intentions to help them with their problem by educating them on Kratom has been a huge success. 

At first, the idea of people I know is "oh sweet, just another high". They soon realize there is no high, rather just no desire for Heroin. documents.commentText:
I believe the temporary placement of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine (derived from the plant commonly known as kratom) into Schedule 1 is short-sighted and premature. These compounds, and the plant from which they are derived, have shown promise for weaning individuals from opioid addiction and for non-addictive management of pain not resolved by non-opiate medicines. I am aware that instances of poisoning due to overdose have been reported. These have been small in number and mild in effect when compared to the many reports of overdose due to opiates including legal prescription opioid medications. Placement in Schedule 1 without solid scientific data will make research on effects and medical uses of this plant much more difficult, as it has for derivatives of cannabis species. This will likely make control of the plant and derivatives more difficult, as it has with cannabis.

I have heard much cynicism about DEA's use of an FDA review of medical uses of cannabis and derivatives as cover for refusal to reconsider Schedule 1 classification of cannabis. It's widely reported that DEA's original scheduling of cannabis was politically-motivated and premature. Placing cannabis in Schedule 1 drastically complicated and research on effects of and therapeutic uses for cannabis and derived compounds. Because of this, relatively little research has been done. Thus, FDA found little in the literature because studying the plant is so difficult - due to Schedule 1 classification. Meanwhile, FDA has approved generations of opioid compounds for pain alleviation despite the addiction and overdose risks. Addiction to legal opioids has become the addiction curse of our times. FDA may fall back on the clinical studies generated in support of these drugs. Real-world use has shown that the potential for addiction and abuse is huge, and the need for alternatives very real. Plainly numerous states and individuals disagree with the Schedule 1 classification of cannabis, and would argue that cannabis is less dangerous as a drug of abuse than FDA-approved opioid pharmaceuticals. 

My advice: go slowly. Another instance of declaring a plant and its derivatives as "no recognized medical uses" despite all the anecdotal uses reported will only tar the reputations of both agencies further, and create further cynicism about the way that DEA classifies plants and their derived compounds. Let some pharmacologic data be generated before you make the final decision. At least then the medical/scientific community will be behind you. There are real dangerous drugs out there - cocaine, heroin, oxycontin... Save yourself the trouble with kratom until you know for sure you have to go after it.

I am opposed to the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, schedule 1 controlled substances.  
This is a regulated dietary ingredient with negligible if any risk to public health as an herbal plant.  Some may have combined it with other risky chemicals, but any harm incurred was caused by the chemicals it was combined with, rather than the kratom itself.  It has helped many people with many things as other herbal ingredients have, not to mention the benefits of coffee.  It is no more harmful to public health than coffee.  There is no potential for abuse.  People using it are productive members of society and the benefits of this herbal substance aid in their being so.  I had used this in 2013, and it would help ease tension and anxiety of daily living and it would also help me feel more motivated to get things done around the house and with my life.  This herbal is very unlikely to be any sort of gateway drug any more than coffee.  There are way more common and even legal 'gateway drugs' available, such as alcohol.  When I think of other legally available medicines or substances, the terms like abuse, dependence, or gateway drugs, seem very contrived, as many items available that actually do harm, like acetaminophen, alcohol, chemically infused cigarettes, are all readily available.  If someone is in chronic or frequent pain, do we say they have an ibuprofen dependence, habit, or are they abusing it?  People should have the choice to possess or use a harmless plant if it gives them relief or helps them function.  There is a health care crisis in this country now and an opiate crisis as well.  Kratom is helpful in lessening both of these to an extent, with negligible if any danger.  
 I am aware of the Wiley Act defining a drug as shall include all medicines and preparations recognized in the United States Pharmacopoeia or National Formulary for internal or external use, and any substance or mixture of substances intended to be used for the cure, mitigation, or prevention of disease of either man or other animals. People are not animals; they have dominion over animals.  And Kratom doesn't cure, mitigate, or prevent any diseases so it's not even a drug.  
Sincerely,
S. Greenberg

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam:
Thank you for allowing public comments regarding this issue. I am a 39 year old female, US Army Veteran, mother of 2, full time Assistant Lab Manager at a small Neuroscience Research lab, and fianc to a wonderful man. I am writing this to respectfully request the DEA/FDA not place any of the alkaloids found in Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) on any Scheduled drug list. 
During my active military service, I was involved in a training incident that left me with a lifelong chronic back injury that I will always need pain relief for in order to function as a productive member of society and have the quality of life we all deserve. I was medically discharged after 2  years of service. A devastating blow since I had planned on a career in the Army. I was studying to be a helicopter pilot, hoping to continue in a medivac unit like the one I was in. 
A recent MRI has shown Osteoarthritis, Degenerative Disk Disease, bulging disks, spinal stenosis, multiple internal hemangiomas and a Tarlov cyst in the right SI joint. From this I often suffer from pain over my entire back and hips, sciatic pain in both legs, pulled back muscles and am now nursing a shoulder injury. I have been on and off of many pain medications for the last 20 years. When I was young and more resilient, I could go significant lengths of time without medication, but still suffered several instances of complete back failure, where I was unable to work or function without physical assistance for a week or more at a time. I was lucky that I had an excellent support system. As I age, however, my ability to rebound has been significantly reduced. My pain is constant. I was prescribed Hydrocodone/APAP 5/325 about two years ago from the VA. In that short time, my tolerance has nearly quadrupled. I feared where it was leading me. I dont want to be a statistic. I dont want to be tethered to synthetic opioid medications that are known to be addictive, damaging to the liver/kidneys, and potentially deadly. The thought of that being my reality for the rest of my life is terrifying!
I heard of Kratom a month before the DEA announced its intent to emergency schedule it. I was intrigued but skeptical. I work in the sciences, so I studied it, trying to figure out what would indicate the need for emergency scheduling. I was unable to find one significant concern. When the Intent to Schedule was reversed, I took a leap of faith and ordered some. I cannot sufficiently describe how glad I am that I did. Since starting with this simple, natural plant product, I have reversed my opioid intake back to my original levels and plan to taper off the remaining doses over the next two months. I have had no withdrawal symptoms other than RLS from the sudden reduction in hydrocodone. My pain is minimal though still present, and my OIC is no longer a problem which is a bonus I hadnt expected. I have never experienced the high that the DEA claims it causes. The one time I took too much the sensation was unpleasant (dizzy, shaking, wobbly eyes) and definitely not something anyone would intentionally go looking for, but I never feared for my health or safety like I did with opioids. With the right amount of Kratom, beyond pain relief, Ive regained a clear headedness and energy level that the prescription meds took away from me. If a medication causes exhaustion and lethargy when it is supposed to be improving ones quality of life, it isnt really doing its job and its time to find something that will.
The risks that Kratom poses are minimal when compared to other legal substances. There has been no loss of life from Kratom alone and a relatively low number of calls to poison control centers when compared to products like alcohol and tobacco. Even soap pods are more dangerous than Kratom if you are going to use that as a measure for risk assessment. Of the deaths where the individuals had Kratom in their system, it is unfitting to suggest Kratom was at all involved without knowing the exact levels of all compounds found. It may just suggest that they were trying to get off the drugs that ultimately killed them by switching to Kratom and had a relapse. If true and they had been off for a while, it is reasonable to suspect that they took the same amount of their drug as they had previously, which could absolutely cause an overdose. The worst that can happen if too much Kratom is ingested is vomiting, which will remove it from the system leaving you with nothing more than wasted product. As for the addictive nature of Kratom, while I have not tried stopping it, anecdotal evidence suggests it is typically no worse than caffeine withdrawals. That is a risk I am willing to take.
 It is time for our government to start letting the American people manage our pain and health as we see fit. Please do not ask me to go back to that life on legal drugs that I despised and feared. Please keep Kratom legal and available for all.
Sincerely,
Amanda Newingham

My name is unimportant. I am a 35 year old white female. I am a traditionally published author (fantasy fiction). I have worked in the past, full-time, for a multimillion dollar online clothing company as their Editor-in-Chief. I handled all social media, blogging, and creative needs. I started using kratom over three and a half years ago because of anxiety. I've dealt with depression and general anxiety for as long as I can remember and I have never been able to find anything that has ever worked, except for kratom. When I initially heard about the potential ban, I cried. I've tried every drug on the market ... nothing but horrible side effects, weight gain, expensive bills (I don't have insurance because I'm a freelancer) and now that I *have* found something, the DEA is taking it away??? Why? This makes no sense to me. I use it responsibly. I've never used drugs in my life. I've never even had a speeding ticket. I abide every law. I love my children, my life, and this country. I thought we lived in a free country, and in a free country, it should be up to its citizens to decide what they put into their bodies. This is a natural substance. Marijuana has just been approved for recreational use in several states, but the DEA is about to ban something that is harmlessly being used to HELP people combat things like mild anxiety?? It's as harmless as valerian root. St. John's Wort can be dangerous when taken with SSRIs, but it is still allowed on the market, but kratom posses a problem? This is heartbreaking. I don't mean any disrespect, but the evidence that is being put forward in order to ban this substance (it is not a drug) is a joke at best. It can synthesized into a drug, but as of right now, it's an old remedy that's been used for thousands of years, and that's the extent of it. 

Please, please don't do this. I don't generally beg for things. But you're going to risk lives by taking this plant away. I don't use it to keep from using drugs, but there are thousands of individuals who do. I know a great many from interactions on forums who do. Alabama's recent death toll is a great example of this (I'm certain someone has linked to the articles on this). Don't let this become a nationwide tragedy just because a few people had a panic attack over some misinformation. The war on drugs has proven an international failure. Europe is already pushing to end it. We're already on the verge of freeing ourselves of the countless deaths that it has caused since its inception. Billions of dollars of American taxpayers' dollars are being spent incarcerating men and women needlessly, instead of building programs to help educate and rehabilitate drug addicts. Please, don't further the problem by banning yet another substance and creating yet another black market. Kratom will continue to be sold and used in the united states. You are giving the cartels more weapons by doing this. You are handing them inventory. They will celebrate this. I'm not trying to be rude or derogatory. I'm trying to be as realistic as possible. Forget lobbyists. Forget the politics of this. Forget the mainstream media and the social media of this, ask yourselves as human beings, do you really think, personally, that this is going to do anyone any good? Is this plant as evil as it is being made out to be? I could go out to my backyard and find no less than thirteen plants that could induce hallucinations, seizures, a coma, or even death (my husband and I also own and run a commercial landscaping business--we know plants). If someone wants to 'get high' from a plant, they are going to do it. You can go from one plant to the next, from now until eternity, and you will never outlaw stupidity. What you can do, is put your time and effort into providing free rehab programs, free drug counseling, etc. Look at ending this war, not continuing it. 

Don't ban kratom. Don't continue this madness. Too many people are using this to keep from using dangerous synthesized drugs that they started taking because of other natural substances that the DEA have already banned. Just, stop. Look at solutions. Don't simply say 'no.' Don't just come to the public with problems. Come to us with solutions. Right now, all the DEA does is come to the public when they see that the public is doing perfectly fine, they take away whatever is making them perfectly happy, then leave them with a huge problem that the public is left to solve on their own.

To Whom It May Concern, 

I wanted to share a little bit about my positive experiences and outcomes related to oral kratom consumption. I first tried kratom when I was about 21. I had struggled with mild substance abuse in my past, including substances like marijuana, painkillers, and alcohol, yet felt no desire to use kratom on a ritualistic basis. I could simply take it as needed, and leave it in my closet for weeks or months without thinking about it. I would use it on and off from that time until the time of writing this when I am 25. So far, the benefits I have seen are extraordinary. I can't stop telling my friends and loved ones how much potential it has, but I am becoming worried about its future. 
My dad, my sister, and myself all suffer from extreme allergies. We are constantly blowing our noses, with tissues always stuffed in our pockets and lying about the house. Once I take a small dose of kratom, about 3 capsules worth of around 2-3 grams, my allergies completely subside for the majority of the day. I have tried so many different allergy remedies and none have provided me any relief remotely close to what kratom does. I am continually astonished to realize it is no coincidence. My sister has noted the same effect. I only wish my dad were around so I could have given him some. 
Furthermore, I suffer from some pretty erratic digestion issues. I often used to have to go several times a day and the consistency of bowel movements were often irregular. I notice that whenever I take kratom, the bm's become much more regular and healthy. 
Another effect I noticed is that it is an enjoyable high but one that is mild and does not beg for me to keep taking it. I have found it is most enjoyable in low doses, where my concentration is improved so I can work on my college coursework. Lastly, I have noticed how it addresses anxiety issues within myself. I am a very shy and introverted individual that struggles to make simple conversations with people. Rather, when I can turn to a plant instead and only in times when I deem necessary, I immediately notice a relaxation that helps eliminate worry that could get in the way of me communicating my thoughts in a smooth and friendly manner. Even when somedays when I have an anxiety pit in my stomach and it persists throughout the day, once the kratom starts to kick in it remarkably vanishes.
I have heard countless reports of how many lives have been positively affected by kratom usage. I think its important that people begin to take another look at not only how it can help people, but at how much better and safer it can be than more conventional medicines or highs. I urge the DEA to truly consider what the people are saying and conduct research to help us all find out what this remarkable plant has in store and if it really possesses anything to warrant the extreme accusations the DEA made when first proposing an emergency scheduling. Thank you for listening to this one man's voice.

documents.commentText:
1. Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

2. If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

3. Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

4. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

5. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

6. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

7. (and politically important) Since no-one really knows how Kratom actually works, or why, or if it causes non-trivial harm, pre-emptive banning of Kratom just looks like the DEA is pandering to Big Pharma to conspire to eliminate actual and potential competition to Big Pharma's commercial position with its drug products. This will only inspire more distrust of Government. Since the DEA has already lost most trust and credibility, can the DEA really afford this?

8. (and perhaps most important) Kratom may not actually be a "drug," in that like Cannabis it is not a mono-molecular chemical with one simple metabolic action. Kratom may be more of a psychedelic with complex interactions with multiple metabolic and psychological processes, with outcomes as much or more dependent on user-preconditions than on the "drug" itself. Perhaps this kind of nuance and complexity is outside the ability of the DEA's operating paradigm to grasp, in which case the DEA should revise its conceptual basis and enter the exciting new world of dealing with complex non-linear open systems with emergent properties and events.

As a veteran and author of a stress management program being used by NATO forces around the world, I believe complementary alternative medicine plays an important role in the treatment of returning veterans, many of whom are addicted to prescribed narcotic painkillers and variety of psychotropic drugs. 

The long term effects of these prescription drugs often leads to a lifetime addiction and declining mental and physical health. Herbal medicine and, particularly, herbs like, Kratom (Mitragyna speciose) has a place in reducing stress and alleviating pain for the veteran community. More importantly, Kratom is much safer with fewer side-effects over the long term, when used in therapeutic doses. 

Moreover, the small number of cases where Kratom resulted in complications was because of other drugs used in conjunction with this herb, or exceeding the therapeutic dosage. 

Therefore, rather than putting the regulatory cart, before the horse, any classification of Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug should be based on scientific study, and not mere conjecture and fear based notions. After all, veterans stand to benefit from this natural herb.

To Whom it May Concern at the DEA,

Hello, I am a 39-year-old writer and mom. I work from home raising my son and writing freelance articles and novels. I struggle with scoliosis, tendonitis (in my wrists, from typing), and depression. I've taken many steps to remain healthy. I dip my hands and wrists in paraffin wax at night, and use an ergonomic mouse, keyboard, and desk chairs. I exercise at least twice a week at the gym, and rarely drink alcohol. When the pain in my back, neck, or shoulders becomes too much, my doctor typically prescribes me Hydrocodone, Tramadol or Naproxen. It helps a little bit, but it also makes me feel "out of it" and woozy, and worried about functioning properly.

Over the summer, I tried Kratom for the first time. I typically mixed a teaspoon or two of the powder in with my fruit smoothie. The results have been terrific. Not only does the pain in my back, neck, and wrists go away--enabling me to write with full strength--but it helps with my anxiety and depression, as well. On the days that I don't take it, I have never personally experienced any unpleasant withdrawl symptoms. The only side effect I've noticed from time to time has been constipation, which I treat with magnesium supplements. Otherwise, Kratom has been a complete blessing in my life. It doesn't make me feel "high" like the prescription opiates do. I feel capable, relaxed, and pain-free. 

I was very distressed to learn that the DEA may ban this plant outright without further research. Its consumption has greatly improved my quality of life, and hasn't harmed me in any way. I have not heard of anyone overdosing on it--from what I understand, it's impossible to do so. (source: https://www.kratomscience.com/2013/03/18/can-you-overdose-on-kratom-in-short-no/)

From what I've read, it is far less dangerous than prescription opiates, and cannot accurately be categorized with them (source: https://www.zamnesia.com/blog-kratom-vs-opium-n425). Based on the opiate epidemic in this country, I truly believe that anything that might help prevent deaths from opiates, or help addicts taper off those drugs, while at the same time treating everyday people's pain in a safe manner, is well worth keeping legal.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read my comment.

Sincerely,

Sarah Skilton

From birth to present Ive had a disorder called Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPD), and from birth until about 3 years ago, its had been a problem. A short definition of this disorder is that the bodys natural internal clock runs backwards. Whereas the normal clock is being tired at night and awake during the day is something impossible for someone with DSPD to achieve. Our brains produce sleep/awake chemicals backwards to where night chemicals such as Melatonin are being produced during the day, leaving the day chemicals to be produced during the night. With my natural internal clock, Im am absolutely unable to fall asleep before 6am-8am. Leaving me awaking around the hours of 2pm-4pm. Imagine a normal person being forced to lay in bed all day, and then also being forced to stay awake all night. That is my life but vice versa. When I say during the day Im tired I dont mean I need a cup of coffee tired, I mean I have to force myself to move or get dressed, unable to even make it through a conversation without my eyes closing tired. All of my life, all day Ive forced myself to stay awake through this just so at night when Im wide awake, I can fail horribly at forcing myself to sleep, which always resulted in a lot of laying quietly, in the dark, alone, and watching the alarm clock for hours.
My education, my employment, my social life, and my relationships were all affected by this one disorder. Not to mention once I had a child, sleeping during the day was no longer an option, there were many days I went with no sleep at all. With the crippling effect this took on my quality of life; my mental health was extremely affected. I sought help from counsellors, therapists, psychiatrists, and doctors. The end result was a lot of medication with little relief. With several pills I was able to sleep at night but nothing could combat the tiredness during the day. I tried many medications to try and treat this tiredness but they all ended with side effects that I were unmanageable. Such as Wellbutrin leading to a lifelong seizure disorder. Causing me repeated seizures, even after discontinuing the medication. I still have seizures to this day and must take a seizure medication now and for the rest of my life. There were other medications the doctors had tried for my tiredness that had countless short term adverse effects as well, such as hallucinations, suicidal thoughts, increased anxiety, headaches, fogginess, memory loss, I could go on and on. 
After professional help ended with more negative than positive effects, I experimented with harder drugs for relief. For a while I thought that this was the answer, until the symptoms of drug addiction really took root. I lost my familys trust, love and acceptance, every penny I could get my hands on, my self-worth, my home, my sanity, and I became a thief, a small time criminal. Most importantly I lost my son. I was deemed an unfit parent and& I was. Long story (not so) short, I decided enough was enough and after years of dependency I suffered cold turkey withdrawals and checked into rehab. Once I completely kicked the habit, I spiraled into an even darker state of depression because not only was I controlled by my disorder again, but I also had to deal with the reality of everything the addiction robbed me of.

I want to be able to say that Kratom has given me my life back, but before Kratom, I truly did not have a life. Kratom literally gave me life. I now have a better outlook on a life that I had all but given up on. When I heard of the ban they had planned, my heart sunk as I realized it might all be over. I cant go back to the place I was in before Kratom. I just cant. Im unable to comprehend that the people who are there to protect our lives and our families, would put me into such a dark place again. If this ban goes through, my life is honestly over. Kratom has become my last chance at life, and the best option for my quality of  life.

Every death in the US that has the word 'kratom' attached to it, has been polydrug use, with prescription drugs being the most likely cause. Kratom just happened to be in their body along with several, actually harmful drugs. Another example is the 'Krypton' samples listed in the DEA letter of intent, these samples of 'krypton' contained tramadol (O-des), which is another prescription drug that is more harmful than kratom. Its not fair to ban a plant, because of some unscrupulous vendors spiking their products with the more dangerous pharmaceuticals. It would be like banning a blood pressure medication because some batches were contaminated with the wrong drug. That would never happen, the companies that have sent out contaminated, FDA approved drugs, are still in business, and this is with the oversight of the FDA. The beneficial medicine itself would never be subject to banning because of the actions of a few individuals/companies. Ive reviewed all the toxicology reports of so called 'deaths' related to kratom, and still I haven't seen one where somebody died from kratom alone. As usual, its the pharmaceuticals (as with krypton) that are causing the problems.

  Its backward and draconian to ban kratom at a time when its needed the most. People would definitely rather get kratom from a regulated source, as long as its still affordable, but no agencies are willing to help with this task. In fact placing it in Schedule 1 prevents this from happening. Just because something becomes popular (no doubt because of the media) does not mean its a public health risk. In fact its more like a big-pharma crisis since kratom cannot be patented, and it really appears that this move is merely to help big pharma retain its profits, which are ill-gained by keeping America hooked on pharmaceuticals. This is backwards and should not be this way. Concerning the fact that the alkaloid content cannot be guaranteed, again the plant itself should not suffer because of this. Its no different with Kava, anything coming from nature cannot be guaranteed to have the same exact alkaloid content every time (as with 'bad batches' of pharmaceutical drugs). People are willing to accept these fluctuations because the benefit of not letting painkillers control ones life is worth the variation in potency. Even with these variations, kratom is still not very harmful. With the support of the Agencies (FDA/DEA), we can assure a more knowledgeable doctor base as well as a more stable alkaloid content coming from vendors. We need to help these vendors meet regulatory requirements, and we need to help doctors and laboratories continue to get more knowledge about these natural medicines. Alcohol is still a bigger threat to the public than kratom will ever be.

  Another important fact to look at is the states that considered banning kratom, but decided against it. This would not happen if kratom truly was the scourge its purported to be. No State Government would allow a dangerous drug to continue to be sold, after examining it, during this era of RC's and bathsalts. Yet this is exactly what has happened in quite a few states concerning kratom. Thats because after reviewing the evidence that is available, its shown kratom is not as dangerous as was thought. I realize that 'technically' there arent enough US studies done on kratom to determine thats its totally safe, but placing it in schedule 1 just guarantees this outcome. If were going to refer to science as the reason, we should let science do its job un-obstructed by Public and Private interests. Its not an emergency, therefor should not be put up for an emergency ban. 600+ calls to poison control is a very small number, aspirin gets more poison control calls in a year. This pre-emptive war on kratom flies in the face of American values of Freedom and Liberty, not to mention the generally accepted culture of open-ness in science, as well as free market values. If the people are demanding it more and more, that alone is not a reason to ban it. Yet reading the DEA letter of intent, it seems kratoms popularity is the sole reason for its banning. Referring over and over to how much is seized, and how many people are reported to have 'abused' it, is not evidence that it should be banned. Its evidence that the American people have spoken, and they are saying they want a way out of the pharmaceutical trap that has been created for us. documents.commentText:
Dear DEA Administrators,

I am writing in support of keeping Kratom as it is currently, not scheduled.  I am a clinical psychologist and have served on Active Duty in the United States Navy.  I am also a student in psychopharmacology and am currently obtaining a Masters Degree in Clinical Psychopharmacology.  My experience and education has provided me with multiple lenses from which to view Kratom.  

Since hearing about Kratom a few years ago, I was at first skeptical but have learned overtime that it does not appear to have an adverse impact on my patients that use it.  In fact, those who have started or have been using it seem to improve and/or remain stable. Most significantly, my patients who suffer from combat related PTSD have seen major improvements in their relationships with friends and family.  Usually, when a patient presents with PTSD they have withdrawn from family and friends and are extremely anxious and depressed.  I have seen patients not respond to traditional  pharmaceuticals and then use Kratom and ultimately see considerable improvement in their overall symptom profile.  In addition to PTSD patients, I have seen many chronic pain patients during my career.  These patient usually end up addicted/dependent upon opiate pain medications and they ultimately end up extremely depressed and unable to come off their opiates due to the psychological withdrawal that causes a very long period of depression.  I have seen a couple of these patients stop using their opiates and have now started using Kratom.  At first I found this to be alarming and saw it as just a replacement but then I noticed something different.  With my opiate patients their dosages just seemed to keep increasing, while with the Kratom patients, they continued to have the same effect without increasing the dosages.  Additionally, my opiate patients often appeared "high" or "out of it", while patients that had used Kratom that day appeared completely lucid and coherent.  

In my own research on Kratom it appears to have different aspects to it than do more traditionally used substances that usually cause addiction.  Kratom appears to have a "ceiling effect", meaning even if you increase the dosage, the effect of Kratom does not increase.  Similar to caffeine, when you consume too much caffeine the effects are not visible and/or become uncomfortable.  But I think a lot of people agree that 1-2 cups of coffee get them going in the morning.  They also will tell you they are not addicted to it, but if we made coffee suddenly illegal I guarantee there would but a very large uproar and people would appear that they were addicted.  You can really like something and its effects withoutt it being addictive.  This is very important when it comes to the addiction cycle and the Dopamine Reward System.  Substances that "light up" the dopamine reward system in a fast way are more likely to be abused.  This is why "crack" cocaine is so highly addictive as is "shooting up" heroin.  These substances hit the dopamine circuitry so quickly that the "reward" and feeling of pleasure is overwhelming and hence make these substances highly susceptible to addiction and abuse.  Kratom likely has some effect on the dopamine reward system, just like tobacco and caffeine,  however it does not appear that it "hijacks" the system such as cocaine, alcohol, and opiates.  There is also research showing that certain strains of Kratom can have an effect on the serotonin system which could account for its anti depressant, anti anxiety effects.  

I am urging you to not schedule Kratom as I have seen it to be very beneficial for a great number of people.  I have not, up to this point, seen anyone have an adverse reaction or  addictive response to this substance.  It scares me to see my patients have to stop using Kratom.  I fear that banning this substance will actually cause great harm to my patients.  I fear that some will start using their opiate medications again, or worse, they won't be able to obtain their opiate medications and will turn to street available drugs such as alcohol or heroin.  There is something very unique about this substance, please do not ban it.  Please allow scientists to research so that they might be able to synthesize medications from the plants useable molecular backbone.  I do have significant fears if this ban were to actually happen.  Thank you for your time.  

Sincerely,

Anonymous

documents.commentText:
First, let me thank your agency for allowing a comment period on this proposal.

As an emergency department pharmacist, I see many overdoses. Although in my area the predominant type of OD we see in the ER is stimulant-related, opioid overdoses are not unheard of. I believe that kratom potentially has an important medical use, specifically for those trying to wean off of opioids or those abstaining from opioids. Additionally, it is not known to cause respiratory depression. We desperately need to study this property further in order to isolate its mechanism. This could open the door to new analgesics without adverse respiratory effects.

All substances have a dose at which they become toxic. Additional study of kratom may allow us to learn the mechanism of its toxicity, and potentially develop an antidote. It will also allow us to document its adverse effects. For example, does it cause constipation like typical opioids? If not, I can see it being a treatment alternative for chronic pain patients.

I would also like to point out that the potential for abuse is not known. However, this is testable and I would like to see scientific evidence documenting the potential for abuse of kratom before classifying it as Schedule I. I understand that it has been involved in 15 drug-related deaths over the past 2 years, but that 14 of those cases involved polypharmacy. Going by those numbers alone, (since the total number of users does not seem to be available) it seems far safer than any opioid on the market or on the street. Again, more science documenting the relative safety or danger of kratom is needed.

Finally, I hope you consider the ramifications of scheduling these substances on our justice system. Many kratom users are just people trying to deal with chronic pain, addiction, or withdrawal. Enacting this proposal will either turn them into criminals (because they will still be using it) or it will force them to use opioids which may have more risks. I do not believe the punishment for carrying a Schedule I substance fits the "crime" in this case.

Thank you for your consideration.

I am writing to try to fight the rising tide of people who seem to think that Kratom is harmless & should remain legal for 
purchase by anyone over 21 years of age.
I would like Kratom to become a Class 1 drug on December 1, 2016. 
I realize I am certainly in the minority. Lots of drug money has been spent to be sure that Kratom stays out there on the 
market.
In the summer of 2013, my 36 year old son, Guy Garcia, began using Kratom to help with depression. He later told me that 
he became addicted to it after taking it ONLY 3 TIMES!
His life deteriorated after that & by the fall his wife had kicked him out of the house & he was living with his step-father and
me. 
He tried narc-a-non, but could not work the program. We were paying for private counseling for him to kick Kratom & get his 
life back on track. We did not realize that he was still using.
On the evening of December 24, 2013, after what I believe was his last ingestion of this "harmless herb," he had a grand-
mal seizure in our home.  Needless to say, it was horrific. His 3 year old son saw the whole thing! The seizure was very long 
& when it ended, he had no pulse & no respiration. My husband performed CPR until Paramedics arrived. When we 
mentioned Kratom they immediately knew it was a possible overdose. They finally got his heart beating after long work & 
left for the ER at Denver Health Medical Center. His heart stopped again on the way to the ER & they got it beating again.
Once in the ER, his heart stopped again. The Doctors were told of his Kratom use & treated him as a possible overdose.
After about an hour, they stabilized his heart beat & did a C.A.T. scan on the way to I.C.U. They tried to give us hope.
He was kept on life support until December 16, since he never regained consciousness. They did the tests to prove brain
death. He was brain dead & on the morning of December 17, Donor Alliance took him away. The only good thing that came
out of his death was that he saved 5 lives with donated organs.
The coroner determined that his death was due to an "apparent acute Mitragynine toxicity." 
To us (his family), it was not just apparent, it was surely any overdose. I know he had been desperate to feel better, 
Desperation drives people to do bad things to their bodies.
I have read many testimonies singing the praises of Kratom. In my opinion, the benefit is getting your "fix." This is a 
dangerous chemical that should not be readily available to ANYONE. I feel certain that many more people than statistics
show have died from Kratom use.
PLEASE RECONSIDER MAKING KRATOM A CLASS 1 FELONY DRUG!!!!!!
My son was a wonderful young man, with a wonderful family & he lost EVERYTHING to Kratom. We, his wife, his son, all his
other family & friends, love him & miss him still. I will mourn his death until the day I die! I will never stop missing him. 
KRATOM IS NOT HARMLESS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

documents.commentText:
Kratom should absolutely NOT be placed on the Schedule of Controlled Substances.

My name is Jane, I'm 34 years old, I'm a married mother of one child, and I'm an office manager for my church.  I also have endometriosis, an incurable condition that causes intense pain on an intermittent basis.  For the past three years, kratom tea has helped me cope with the symptoms of this condition without the use of opiate painkillers.

Addiction and drug abuse are rampant and escalating, which is just one reason why it's absolutely counterproductive to ban or restrict an herbal supplement that helps to support people's health and well-being, in turn reducing the use of prescription drugs.  Without kratom, which helps to soothe and ease the extremely painful symptoms I experience with endometriosis, my choices would be very limited.  I would have to either take prescription opiates, which I am adamantly opposed to using, or undergo a hysterectomy at the age of 34.  Aside from the negative effects on my health, a hysterectomy would also be emotionally devastating, since I'm hoping to have a second child.  I am not exaggerating when I say that kratom is what is preserving my fertility, albeit indirectly.

The existing research is overwhelmingly in favor of the safety of kratom.  While there have been some negative reports, those reports are remarkably few, especially when compared to the number of negative incidents involving everything from energy drinks to over-the-counter medications to other common herbal supplements.  Furthermore, nearly all of those negative incidents have involved at least one of the following factors: adulterated or contaminated products (https://academic.oup.com/jat/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/anatox/35.4.242); combining kratom with multiple other substances; and modified kratom products, meaning the plain leaf (normally crushed or powdered for use as a tea) was converted into a concentrated extract or tincture.

This does NOT mean that kratom should be banned or "scheduled."  Instead, those who have studied kratom extensively are in favor of regulation that would require vendors to test their products for contamination and purity.  Indeed, the reputable vendors already do this.  We absolutely desire and recommend these kinds of quality-control measures, which could prevent the majority of negative experiences.  Most kratom is already sold in plain leaf form.  If we had regulation requiring that kratom products be sold only in plain leaf form, the sales of modified or concentrated products would be reduced even further.

Dr. Walter C. Prozialeck summarizes this quite clearly: "After evaluating the literature, I can reach no other conclusion than, in pure herbal form, when taken at moderate doses of less than 10 to 15 g, pure leaf kratom appears to be relatively benign in the vast majority of users." (jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524)

Surely we are beyond pretending that banning substances actually makes them disappear.  By "scheduling" or banning products, our government isn't actually controlling them; on the contrary, they are abdicating control.  They are simply handing the regulation of that product over to the black market.

People have been using kratom responsibly for many years with no negative effects.  Making kratom a controlled substance would cause irreparable damage to me personally, to thousands of others like me, and to our economy with the loss millions of dollars in legitimate sales and commerce (https://www.botanical-education.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/BEA-Economic-Impact-Report_V3-1.pdf).  Please don't rob us of our choices and our freedom to make our own decisions about how we manage and support our health.

To whom it may concern,

     I would like to strongly discourage the scheduling of Kratom and it's active alkaloids to schedule I.  I am urging you as a pharmacist and healthcare professional from Ohio.  Everyday I see first hand the effect that heroin, prescription drugs, and alcohol addiction has on my patients. I can tell you with great confidence that the data currently does not support this emergency scheduling.  
     Being a pharmacist I base all of what I know and practice on evidence based medicine. Currently the evidence does not show that Kratom is an imminent danger to the public.  The negative affects currently known are relatively mild, and less severe than alcohol, which is readily available.  People using Kratom long term may have some withdrawal, but it's relatively mild.  Even withdrawal from heroin is less dangerous than alcohol withdrawal, which can actually kill a person. Many many people use Kratom responsibly and a high percentage use it just to be able to function in daily living.  Whether it's for chronic pain or to help with opioid dependency. Please don't take ways this plant for them to use.  Of course if something is available a small percentage will abuse it, as is the case with alcohol or coffee. But as history in this country has shown, prohibition doesn't work! Making something illegal doesn't make it go away, it just makes it less safe.  Kratom will still be around on the black market if it is banned and there it has a higher chance of being adulterated.  Not to mention the thousands of otherwise law abiding citizens that will become overnight felons if this ban goes through.  I'm asking you, the DEA to allow more research on whether or not this plant truly is dangerous or medicinal before taking action. Only after several independent, peer reviewed journals and research has been published will we know for sure.  
     As of right now no deaths have been attributed to Kratom alone so there is not a strong reason to ban it yet.  The same can't be said for alcohol which we know kills thousands every year and is responsible for billions in healthcare costs.  I'm not saying we should ban alcohol because we already know that doesn't work.  But how can you make a case for banning Kratom and pretend like alcohol is ok.  It just doesn't make sense.  Kratom has no reason to be banned in its natural plant form.  Perhaps the extracts and purified isolated compounds could be dangerous, but not the plant or its leaves. They decided rather than ban it, to just control it sensibly by passing the Kratom Control Act. http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/BillStatus.asp?DocNum=5526&GAID=12&DocTypeID=HB&SessionID=85&GA=98

Restrict sale to only adults similar to tobacco and alcohol and ensure that no adulteration happens to the supply.  If you ban it, you will be doing much more harm than good.

Thank you for your time,
Anonymous Pharmacist, PharmD, RPh

I am writing to express my opposition to the proposed scheduling by the DEA of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragyine.  For a few years now, I have ingested kratom daily as a tea and/or by mixing it with water, and have found it to be immensely helpful in alleviating back pain while at my desk job.  Kratom allows me to perform my job pain-free, while keeping my head clear and my mind sharp.  I am no longer dependent on taking over-the-counter pain relievers.  As a result, I have become a happier and more productive member of society.  Moreover, I believe that kratom has been extremely beneficial in helping me to live a cleaner, more healthy life.  Whereas I used to drink three to four cups of coffee a day, I now drink two to three cups a week.  In addition, I have decreased my consumption of alcohol and have strived to exercise more.   My social anxiety has also curbed since beginning to take kratom.  

Aside from the benefits that I have experienced, I personally know someone who has been able to ween off of suboxone and kick their opiate addiction by supplementing with kratom.  The comments submitted to date appear to lend credence that kratom can be used to effectively and safely lessen or alleviate certain symptoms of opiate withdrawal.  

I believe kratom to be an incredibly safe herb with multiple potential benefits. Along with the anecdotal evidence provided by people like me commenting on this issue (and literally thousands of years of anecdotal evidence derived from other users around the globe), the literature published to date confirms the safety of the plant, with not even a single fatality linked to kratom use alone. Importantly, kratom does not make me feel "high," and thus, I cannot imagine that it has any recreational use or risk of abuse. 

Too often in our history, we have banned safe, naturally occurring substances and plants based on misguided fear of the unknown.  This has been hugely detrimental to society, effectively turning productive, law-abiding citizens into criminals.  I urge the DEA to not repeat the mistakes of the past, and to cancel its proposed scheduling of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragyine.

I am a student of history at the University of Connecticut. I'd like to begin first, with a short introduction of myself.

When I was a high school freshman my doctors informed me that I had two precancerous tumors growing in my chest. After a successful surgical procedure had been performed to remove the tumors, I was prescribed a month's supply of the prescription painkiller OxyContin 20mg. In less than a month's time, I had developed a severe addiction to prescription painkillers like OxyContin (oxycodone) and Vicodin (hydrocodone); all of this before my 15th birthday.

For years I struggled to overcome my addiction -- both throughout my high school career and beyond. Unfortunately, nothing I tried could keep me clean for longer than a few weeks or (rarely) a month. Unfortunately for myself and others like me, addictions that are developed in childhood and early adolescence are far more difficult to overcome than those that develop later in life.

Desperate to find an answer to the problem that had caused so much pain to myself and my loved ones and that had controlled the entirety of my teenage life, I decided to look for safe alternatives to prescription opiates (lest I turn to heroin).

That was when I discovered a plant that originates from the South East Asian countries of Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia known as "Mitragyna speciosa" (but is more commonly referred to simply as "kratom"). Kratom is a member of the coffee family and has been used as a natural pain reliever and medicinal plant for thousands of years in Thailand. However, it wasn't until the rapid increase of US cases of prescription opiate dependence that an ulterior use for kratom was discovered:

This plant was found to act as an agonist to the opioid receptors in the human brain. It is about as addictive as coffee and the symptoms of withdrawal are no worse than those for caffeine. It offers people like me a second chance to turn their lives around without having to worry about chasing highs.

I have been using kratom daily for over a year and have never once felt the urge to seek out dangerous narcotics of the kind I had once been dependent on. Without it, I fear I may go back to using the dangerous substances that once had had full control over my life. 

 Kratom has been shown to have very few negative side effects and does not cause respiratory depression (the leading cause of death from synthetic opioids).

Kratom has never been documented to have caused a single death where it was the only substance to have been found in the victim's system. "Association" and causation are not the same.
  
Kratom is not a heroin substitute. It is a medicine.

Lastly, I would like to thank the Drug Enforcement Agency for doing the right thing by allowing kratom users and medical doctors to submit their comments and input. 
  
Sincerely,

Nathan L.

To begin, thank you for this opportunity to express my comments and concerns. Communication and expression of ideas and knowledge is a fundamental element of our government.  

Now, I wont bury the lede any longer; I am adamantly opposed to Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) placing Kratom on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances.

Thank you again for this period to comment and express our views on Kratom. I do believe that, as long as it stays off the scheduled drug list, it will come to be seen as a safe, responsible alternative to prescriptions medications of all kinds.

The very idea of making (another!) plant illegal is absolutely ridiculous - especially in a "free" country. Much like marijuana, the worse that happens if you "overdose" is a nice, long nap. There is no danger in kratom - the stories suggesting it to be harmfull all seem to share the fact that it's user also had other (often several!) dangerous substances/chemicals/medications in their systems. I am a chronic pain sufferer who, having tried nearly every other option out there (from simple over the counter Advil, tylenol, etc, to every prescription strength NSAID available, to steroid injections - which made things FAR worse), I put off using the opioids my dr offered me for many, many years, until the pain simply became too much to bear, I was unable to take care of my family or hold a job, and became depressed to the point of desperation. At only 35, I felt like my life was over. When I finally gave in, it changed my life practically overnight. Not only could I care for myself and my family again, over the next 8 years I was able to build a business that grosses over $800k a year and employs 8 other people. However, I (along with millions of other chronic pain patients) now live in fear of this newest DEA over-reach that's requiring pain management doctors to go against their oaths and cut off the only life-line most of their patients have.
Now, I life in fear that these opioids, which I credit quite literally with saving my life, may be taken away. And worse - cut off suddenly, with no advance warning. In trying to deal with this possibility, my research led me to kratom. I was relieved to find that there was something that, should i be suddenly cut off, I could turn to to ease the symptoms of withdrawal (chemical dependence happens whether you're an addict, or not) and also help with the immeasurable pain I may be forced to return to. I have personally talked to people who have been forced to seek their medications on the streets (what would YOU do if these medications were what separated you from living your life or dying a little more each day?) - some have even turned to *heroin* because it's much easier to find & more affordable, especially in light of the new demand for illegal opioids caused by this crackdown. Much like similar laws against marijuana, and the years of alcohol prohibition before that - making something illegal does NOT make it go away. It merely gives criminals another way to profit, increases violence and the state another option for incarcerating it's citizens (which is probably the whole point, all the guise of "protecting" the public) - and all for choosing to use something that effects no one but themselves. Well, please - STOP trying to save me from myself. Let ME decide how to live my life. And let my children live in a world where their mother is actually there for them, and where crime is DOWN because there's no such thing as illegal drugs for criminals to peddle. THAT would be a free country, and we have NO excuse for doing otherwise Keep kratom legal!
